item.title: Getting there
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Aftermath:

Actually, in the United States, the federal law is supreme in regard to state law in absolutely all matters. As for what is considered a ‘state issue’, that varies based on time period and perspective [for example, slavery in pre-Civil War United States, a ‘popular sovereignty’ issue to many yet a national issue to others]

basically youre saying the constitution means nothing

which is fine, but they should burn it already instead of pretending it matters

item.title: Getting there
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

If the Federal government brings in a law that is beyond the scope of their powers then no, the state governments don’t have to follow it – it’s unconstitutional for the federal law to even exist.

The American constitution, much like Australian’s constitution, delegates law making powers in various areas to the federal government and state government.
For example, in Western Australia radar detectors (which are used to detect police radar) are perfectly legal to own and use. This isn’t the case in any other state. Now our federal government couldn’t come in and legislate with regards to this to introduce uniformity because they aren’t legally allowed to, as per our constitution (which grants the power of law making with regards to roads and transit to the state governments).
If, against all odds, the Australian government did try to legislate in such an area then the state governments wouldn’t have to enforce it, because the federal legislation is unconstitutional. However they may choose to enforce it anyway, but that would be at their discretion.

Read full topic

item.title: Getting there
item.dc:creator: @nacional nacional
item.description:
@nacional wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:26, topic:324902”][quote author=nacional link=topic=421260.msg3095322#msg3095322 date=1263246351]
Pretty sure, the Feds have to abide with the constitution with whatever they do. And everything that falls outside of
the constitution is up for the states to decide. Like drug legalization. And Federal Law is always above State law.
So saying States don’t have to enforce Federal laws is wrong.

Also sure there are medical marijuana dispensaries, but does that doesn’t mean everyone in there has permission
to use and posses the marijuana. So DEA raids might be legal. I actually did some research on this and even though
no one was arrested, the DEA did confiscate the marijuana which is wrong IMO.
[/quote]
Please leave the political discussions to people who actually know even a little bit about the subject. Thanks.[/quote]

Says the person who agree that the states don’t have to follow federal law, what a joke.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: January 11, 2010, 10:20:42 pm[/size][hr][quote=“Mopman, post:27, topic:324902”][quote author=nacional link=topic=421260.msg3095322#msg3095322 date=1263246351]
Pretty sure, the Feds have to abide with the constitution with whatever they do. And everything that falls outside of
the constitution is up for the states to decide. Like drug legalization.
[/quote]

You’re basically right, except the Feds decided that personal consumption of drugs is a matter of restricting trade, because drugs can be carried across state lines. How that means they can regulate personal consumption I dunno, you’d have to ask them or a lawyer ;/[/quote]

NO no no, you ask unhandled cause he knows all about this.

Read full topic

item.title: Getting there
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

it should be pointed out that the US should not be able to MAKE federal laws criminalising personal use of drugs - it is not within their power, its a state matter. they just did it anyway and everyone sat down and took it.

I agree with that, the problem is where it’s not spelled out what the federal government can do where states are concerned they both want to make laws about the issue. The state can always bring the issue before the federal supreme court and get the law declared unconstitutional though, which is what would have to happen to clear the whole thing up.

Read full topic

item.title: Getting there
item.dc:creator: @cooper cooper
item.description:
@cooper wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:16, topic:324902”][quote author=nacional link=topic=421260.msg3094675#msg3094675 date=1263170301]

Cool. But isn’t this contridicting federal marijuana laws? So what difference will it make

States dont have to enforce federal law. If this gets legalized then no state cop can arrest you, only fbi etc.

really doubt it works like that…
[/quote]
That’s exactly how it works…In California, it’s currently legal to run a medical marijuana dispensary, according to state law. Now federal law still says it’s illegal to possess marijuana, so the DEA, a federal agency, has been raiding these dispensaries, despite them being perfectly legal according to state law. Obama recently told the DEA to leave them alone, so I assume these raids have stopped, despite running a dispensary still being illegal according to federal law.[/quote]
Correct. It’s good to see an aspect of U.S. government where federalism is still practiced.

Read full topic
